The class laoder can worry about efficent loading of class files, I was
talking about this specific test case. This specific test case benefits from
keeping the test data in memory.

As for TDD, I've found that it's tough to start with unit tests when all you
have is stories describing functionality. My first test is effectively a
functional test to drive out an API. The unit tests are easier once I have
some method names.

Terry Wilcox
terry.wilcox@...

> From: Levi Cook [mailto:levicook@...]

> Subject: Re: [junit] expensive setup which is definitely only required
> on ce
> 
> 
> I agree that mocks provide excellent utility in this scenario, but 
> class files still need to be read from somewhere (usually disk) too.
> 
> -- Levi
> 
> PS> Maybe its just the projects I'm dealing w/, but I'm finding that 
> TDD is most effective (esp. the Design aspect) when my tests lean 
> towards functional tests. A real challenge seems to be 
> learning how and 
> when to "graduate" functional tests into unit tests. Does 
> this jive w/ 
> anyone's experience?
> 
> 
> On Monday, April 7, 2003, at 02:25  PM, Terry Wilcox wrote:
> 
> > This lets you create a new CSV "file" for every test without the 
> > overhead of
> > disk access.
>
